image.altText: Two men and a woman in suits stand behind podiums in front of a doorway into Parliament House.

props.synopsis: The government will halve the stage 3 tax cuts for the highest earners and use the money to deliver an $804 tax cut across the board.

title.children: Most taxpayers to get $804, but high-end tax cut halved as government rewrites stage 3

image.altText: Steven Marshall smiles.

props.synopsis: Former SA premier Steven Marshall broke a painful 20-year election drought for the Liberals. But his government was ousted after a term, following controversies and a tough health focused election campaign from Labor.

title.children: Steven Marshall led the SA Liberals out of the political wilderness, but his government lasted just one term

image.altText: Rozeleen Kumar standing in a flood-damaged room in her home.

props.synopsis: After two years of floods inundating the east coast of Australia, thousands of customers are still waiting for their claims to be finalised.

title.children: 'I would prefer to deal with Satan': Thousands of 2022 flood victims still waiting on building insurance claims

image.altText: A court build with a columned verandah and a blue coloured building behind

props.synopsis: Dylan Lloyd faces the Adelaide Magistrates Court charged with indecently assaulting a woman in Adelaide’s south in July, after being re-arrested earlier on Wednesday.

title.children: Accused child sex offender faces court on separate indecent assault charge

image.altText: Nancy Bates looks.

props.synopsis: First Nations singer-songwriter Nancy Bates teaches inmates at the Adelaide Women's Prison how to write songs, sing and play the ukulele in what she hopes will prevent them from reoffending.

title.children: Singer-songwriter helps female prisoners through 'life changing' music program

image.altText: Park grass cordoned off with tape and signs

props.synopsis: Contaminated mulch containing asbestos has been found in Sydney's inner west and western suburbs after first being discovered in Rozelle Parklands. How worried should people be about this substance?

title.children: How dangerous is the asbestos found in mulch around Sydney? Here's what we know

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie gestures with his hand in front of buildings out of focus

props.synopsis: Former South Australian premier Steven Marshall is quitting politics, after more than a decade in state parliament.

title.children: Former South Australian premier Steven Marshall set to quit politics

image.altText: Zheng Qinwen celebrates winning her Australian Open semifinal.

props.synopsis: Inspired by Li Na winning the Australian Open in 2014, Zheng Qinwen has given herself every chance of joining her countrywoman as a champion at Melbourne Park after advancing to the semifinals.

title.children: It's 10 years since a Chinese player won the Australian Open. Zheng Qinwen may soon join the roll call

image.altText: Mark McCudden sitting in his office in front of pictures of his family.

props.synopsis: The only pharmaceutical company in Australia which supplies the critical ADHD drug Vyvanse is in the grips of a global shortage, plunging some Australians into fear and uncertainty.

title.children: Australians with ADHD endure months-long shortage of critical treatment drug

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks into a microphone in front of US flags. He has an unhappy expression.

props.synopsis: Nikki Haley proved no real threat to Donald Trump in the New Hampshire primary, but her strategy highlighted some of his vulnerabilities before his likely rematch with Joe Biden, writes North America correspondent Carrington Clarke.

title.children: Trump's anger in New Hampshire followed a win that exposed some weakness

image.altText: A screen shot of the leaked document sits beside an image of Debbie Ngarewa-Packer a co-leader of the Maori Party

props.synopsis: As a minor party in New Zealand's governing coalition pushes ahead with a plan to draft a controversial bill on the country's founding documents, Māori leaders have issued a warning.

title.children: A leaked memo, legal battles and a call-to-action from the Māori king — NZ is on edge

image.altText: An aerial shot of a solar farm with other buildings

props.synopsis: Rapid growth in renewable generation slashed the wholesale cost of power in the national energy grid late last year, and dramatically reduced reliance on coal-fired power.

title.children: Surge in renewables across national grid pushes down wholesale power prices to half their 2022 level

image.altText: People sunbaking at Clovelly Beach

props.synopsis: The current heatwave is set to break temperature records in parts of NSW from today, with the far west expected to bear the brunt of the heat.

title.children: Heatwave to peak in NSW, with far west expected to cop the hottest temperatures

image.altText: A man standing next to a giant tree in the forest.

props.synopsis: Brett Mifsud has travelled to Tasmania for more than 30 years to find and measure the state's largest trees. He fears increasingly frequent and intense fires mean this could be the last generation of giants.

title.children: Tasmania is home to the tallest flowering plants in the world. Fire is now their biggest threat

image.altText: Two men and a woman leave a court building down a ramp

props.synopsis: A 21-year-old man faces court in South Australia's south-east for the first time accused of two counts of death by dangerous driving.

title.children: Padthaway man accused of being drunk in fatal crash with Victorian couple

image.altText: A close up image of an SA Police car.

props.synopsis: The 24-year-old man allegedly assaulted a motorist with a scooter, before assaulting two officers during his arrest in Adelaide's south.

title.children: Man arrested after allegedly attacking man with scooter before assaulting two officers

image.altText: Two men look at a photovoltaic cell that's suspended under lights for inspection.

props.synopsis: Across the Western world, governments are trying to rein in China's ascendancy in green tech manufacturing. But a respected global forecaster has offered a sobering assessment.

title.children: Western efforts to break China's green tech stranglehold 'not possible' this decade, global forecaster says

image.altText: Regalado 2

props.synopsis: Four days after being charged with fraud by the Colorado Securities Commissioner, televangelist Eli Regalado decided to come clean to his supporters.

title.children: Crypto pastor admits to fraud on video, claims 'the Lord told me to' remodel house with funds

image.altText: Men in skates on an ice rink.

props.synopsis: The first Winter Olympics featured athletes in woolly jumpers and tweed jackets with heavy wooden skis strapped to their boots. How times have changed.

title.children: How winter sports have changed in the 100 years since the first Winter Olympics

image.altText: West Indies celebrate a run out in black and white

props.synopsis: The early indications are that he Gabba Test of 2024 will not be a classic, but in 1960, on the occasion of the West Indies's second ever visit to the Queensland capital, the two sides played out one of just two ever Test ties.

title.children: 'The crowd was in a frenzy': Remembering Test cricket's first tie

image.altText: A sign saying James Nash House

props.synopsis: South Australia's Chief Psychiatrist restricts James Nash House from admitting some patients to its Birdwood Ward over concerns that the facility "looks and feels like a prison".

title.children: Adelaide mental health facility restricted from admitting new patients to 'prison-like' ward

image.altText: A swirling red mass sits off the coast of Queensland in a false-colour satellite view of Australia.

props.synopsis: The cyclone is currently a category one but is expected to cross the coast as a category two system on Thursday night, according to the Bureau of Meteorology.

title.children: Cyclone Kirrily declared with impacts expected on Queensland's coast and islands

image.altText: A smiling group of men and women in formal wear at a restaurant.

props.synopsis: The RSPCA says more than half of the members of a committee into the future of duck hunting attended a hunting lobby group dinner while they were still hearing evidence.

title.children: Duck hunting inquiry committee members say dinner with lobbyists had 'no impact' on decision

image.altText: A woman standing and a boy sitting on the back of a bench holding doughnuts with the sea and a jetty behind

props.synopsis: Buying a doughnut is not just a tradition when visiting this South Australian small town, it also contributes to the beautification of the place.

title.children: Buying a Lions Club doughnut is a summer tradition that helps spruce up small SA beach town

image.altText: Kim Williams at a press conference in Canberra

props.synopsis: How does a clarinettist who was a national Lego champion as a boy, a conscientious objector to the Vietnam War, whose first wife was a famous author and comedian and second, the daughter of an Australian prime minister, end up widely known as a media executive?

title.children: Kim Williams was rejected when he applied to run the ABC, aged 29. Now he finally gets his chance

image.altText: Russian plane

props.synopsis: A Russian military transport plane carrying 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war, six crew and three people accompanying them has crashed in Russia's Belgorod region near Ukraine, according to Russia's Defence Ministry.

title.children: Russian transport plane crashes near Ukraine with 65 Ukrainian POWs on board, Russian defence ministry says

subjects.title: Air and Space Accidents and Incidents

image.altText: People cross the road at an intersection in a busy CBD.

props.synopsis: The 624,100 population increase over the past 12 months is equivalent to adding more than the population of Tasmania in just one year.

title.children: Australia's population hits 27 million, nearly two decades ahead of forecast

image.altText: A helicopter ambulance on the beach with a number of emergency personnel.

props.synopsis: Police say three people have died after getting into difficulty in the water at a beach south-east of Melbourne.

title.children: Three people dead, one critical after being pulled from water at Phillip Island beach, police say

image.altText: Photo of Cairns police watch house entrance including signs on door saying 'No Smoking'

props.synopsis: Inside a watch house in Cairns, children as young as 10 are locked into cells designed for adults, sometimes four at a time with their mattresses on the floor.

title.children: Psychologist doesn't understand why Qld government accepts 'abhorrent conditions' in police watch house

image.altText: Alex Zverev shouts with glee after winning the Australian quarterfinal against Carlos Alcaraz.

props.synopsis: Alex Zverev beats a top-five player at a major for the first time, taking down Carlos Alcaraz in four tense sets in their quarterfinal on Rod Laver Arena.

title.children: Alexander Zverev scores stunning win over Carlos Alcaraz to reach Australian Open semifinal

image.altText: The court surface at the Australian Open is inspected.

props.synopsis: Matt Ebden says he was left "a little bit" frustrated and surprised after his Australian Open doubles match was halted due to issues with the court surface at Melbourne Park.

title.children: 'I've never seen it': Australian Open doubles match moved after 'bubbles' appear on court

image.altText: A man pointing

props.synopsis: Donald Trump won the New Hampshire primary just moments after polls closed. But a defiant speech from his rival left the former US president visibly frustrated.

title.children: 'Who the hell was the impostor?': Trump won, Haley lost, but his New Hampshire victory left him angry

image.altText: CoolSeal installation in the City of Charles Sturt

props.synopsis: Los Angeles and other US cities have embraced lighter-coloured "cool roads" in response to climate change and heatwaves. So why isn't Australia doing the same?

title.children: Why hot Australian cities keep laying dark heat-absorbing asphalt, not pale 'cool roads'
